title: RRR
summary: RRR is a fictional story about India's legendary freedom fighters, Alluri Sitarama Raju and Komaram Bheem who fought against the British Raj and the Nizam of Hyderabad respectively.
critic_reviews: People who hand-wring about movies being dead really need to check this one out. RRR proves that, yes, cinema is alive and well, but only if you’re willing, every now and again, to look past your backyard.
S.S. Rajamouli’s RRR is a dazzling work of historical fiction — emphasis on the “fiction” — that makes the moving image feel intimate and enormous all at once.
The thrill of RRR is not the density of its storytelling, though—it’s the exuberance of it.
The battles are bloody and gory, and the set pieces are absolutely massive in scale.
If you thought Hobbs and Shaw were a cute couple, you ain’t seen nothin’ yet; RRR is bromantic action nirvana.
RRR feels simultaneously personal and gargantuan in scope.

It’s about perseverance and the power of working together toward a common goal. Those themes are universally relatable — as is the giddy thrill of watching racist forces of imperial oppression get exactly what’s coming to them.

It may have a tenuous relationship with nuance, but RRR is a bombastic delight. Making the Fast And Furious series look restrained by comparison, it hits the parts Hollywood actioners just can’t reach. Rise! Roar! Revelation!
For all its political determination, RRR is also a musical, and an electrifying one.

Riotous good fun from start to finish, RRR, a fictionalised account of two real-life revolutionaries fighting against the British Raj and Nizam of Hyderabad in 1920s India is being deservedly championed for reminding audiences what big screen entertainment is all about.
Rajamouli shoots the film’s action with hallucinogenic fervor, supercharging scenes with a shimmering brand of extended slow-motion and C.G.I. that feels less “generated” than unleashed.

The movie is such an irresistible and intoxicating celebration of cinematic excess that even after 187 minutes (including intermission or, as the title card announces, “InteRRRval”), you are left exhilarated, not exhausted.

The movie does everything LARGE, whether it’s an action sequence or an emotional connection. By the time the 3-hour running time has expired, most viewers will be exhausted from the nonstop energy of the experience.
I’d say the movie is a lot, but you’d need way more than those four letters to cover it.
Visually exhilarating as it may be, it’s worthwhile to remember that RRR is inspired by true events. It’s a work of historical fiction that’s just as inventive as its thrilling special effects.

Obviously, one film cannot encompass everything, and as the filmmakers have themselves noted, RRR is sheer fantasy. I cannot fault viewers for enjoying RRR so much, whether they ironically lap up the superhuman stunts or get swept up in the thrilling anti-imperial action. I’m concerned more about the timing of it all, the global presence, the recipe for viral success that other filmmakers will be eyeing. It’s an ingenious form of soft-power propaganda, one that can be interpreted as positively asserting an otherwise-marginalized ideology.
It’s all in good, violent fun until it gets to be too much and you realize they’re never going to top their big two-hour-mark throwdown.

reviews.content: This movie would have been better if it was a gay love story, since the love interests of both actors have negligible roles anyway. Rajamouli made a terrible mistake by not letting Ramcharan and NTR kiss onscreen.

I agree with one of the critics that the movie is so loyal to being a legend rather than a story. It is ridiculous from time to time. I cannot say I dislike the movie, but just not sure how to make sense of it.

How much should you celebrate the excess when you start to feel the effects of exhaustion even in the heat of the event?A fair question for this overly long film.
Now, anyone who has seen an Indian film knows what these do, and for thoseHow much should you celebrate the excess when you start to feel the effects of exhaustion even in the heat of the event?A fair question for this overly long film.Now, anyone who has seen an Indian film knows what these do, and for those who haven't seen one, if this is your first, go with my blessing and admiration.Also, as I recently discussed with Top Gun: Maverick. Uncomplicated entertainment can be short-lived, but as long as it serves its purpose and of course has made its profit, the rest is irrelevant.RRR is something along those lines. It's an epic that indulges itself in all possible excesses.It's a bold extravaganza. Cheerful, colorful, musical, violent, extravagant, comical, flamboyant, dramatic and a bit hilarious. All focused on making this story a really really big show. And it works to a certain degree, after all, its shortcomings are clearly plot-related, but when you're making a 3-hour film that intersperses dance and singing sequences with such wacky fights, the least important thing is the story and both the filmmakers and the actors know it.That's why I do recommend and applaud this film for its fearless and ambitious staging. It's a lavish and impressive show there's no doubt about that, it's just that it's not a great film.
If India made Sharknado would it receive such high acclaim? Entertaining, but in no way a good movie.

How can anybody give this huge joke of a movie anything above 0?!? Awful acting, illogical action scenes and a laughable story. I switched off after 20 minutes.The fact that people think that British audiences should feel jealous and angryHow can anybody give this huge joke of a movie anything above 0?!? Awful acting, illogical action scenes and a laughable story. I switched off after 20 minutes.The fact that people think that British audiences should feel jealous and angry at this movie is just bizarre. I think that British audiences couldn’t care less for being depicted as evil a-holes in this movie. Just like American audiences didn’t seem to mind how they were depicted in “Dances with Wolves”. RRR managed to impress audiences around the world at just how bad this movie is.

This film states up front that it's fictitious and that all animals are CGI. Even so, the movie is fantastic fun! It revolves around 2 men who become best friends. Meanwhile, they secretly work to overthrow the colonial imperialists who areThis film states up front that it's fictitious and that all animals are CGI. Even so, the movie is fantastic fun! It revolves around 2 men who become best friends. Meanwhile, they secretly work to overthrow the colonial imperialists who are still dominating India in the 1920s. What makes the story exciting is the way it's told: The action scenes easily rival any from Hollywood. There are moments of beautiful visual imagery. Enjoyable songs are peppered throughout, which includes a dizzying dance number (and stay thru the credits for one more.) The 2 leads are close to superheroes in strength, deed and determination, while the British villains are so evil they're almost twirling their metaphorical mustaches. In typical style of the genre, the emotions are overblown with acting to match, but they're still effective. Even with a completely predictable story and a 3-hour length, there's so much to enjoy that it continually entertains in a big way. (In Telugu with subtitles, although much of the film is in English)

These two were so freakn overpowered that they could tag team Captain America.Two criticisms (sort of):1. This was a 3 hour movie.2. Just make the two friends gay! They only thought of each other, would do anything for each other most of the time, were very touchy, and there were several times where they stared longingly into each other's eyes. It made a real solid connection for the two, don't get me wrong, but me and my friends howled with laughter as we yelled 'Just kiss!' at the television.

I always say that with movies or shows you’ve got to focus on three factors. Interesting characters, interesting story or plot, and interesting scenes or sequences. You can have interesting characters and a simple plot and still have a goodI always say that with movies or shows you’ve got to focus on three factors. Interesting characters, interesting story or plot, and interesting scenes or sequences. You can have interesting characters and a simple plot and still have a good movie. You can have boring characters and interesting plot and still have a good movie. But interesting scenes and sequences, like a really good fight scene isn’t enough. RRR captures both interesting characters and interesting sequences and scenes. The fight scenes are intense and have weight to them due to well made characters who feel fleshed out and full of reason and purpose…you will care about these characters. The production value is felt and seen here. You can pause at almost any moment and see a worth screen shot or walllpaper. It’s a beautiful movie for all the bloodshed you will witness and violence. It’s also violent but not too gory which is nice mix. If you watched any of those garbage Netflix movies featuring big names…you’d be doing yourself a disservice by not watching RRR because RRR is better than all those Greyman, whatever Ryan Renolds ends up in…

.The best superhero movie in yearsI have to try and review this without comparing it to anything directly, because it's not really comparable to other action blockbusters that have disappointed me recently. But I can say that for.The best superhero movie in yearsI have to try and review this without comparing it to anything directly, because it's not really comparable to other action blockbusters that have disappointed me recently. But I can say that for large-scale, big-budget action movies, this is how you do it right. Hollywood isn't incapable of making movies that deliver excitement and emotion, but many pale in comparison to RRR. Again without pointing out any movies in particular (because I don't know what's directly comparable), Hollywood should take notes..

Just what you'd expect from a film called 'Rise Roar Revolt.' Also, 'RRR' may have the greatest bromance in film history: two dudes that love their country start the most honest friendship, but when a terrible truth arises, their bond is putJust what you'd expect from a film called 'Rise Roar Revolt.' Also, 'RRR' may have the greatest bromance in film history: two dudes that love their country start the most honest friendship, but when a terrible truth arises, their bond is put up to the ultimate loyalty test. Just when you thought Jurassic World Dominion killed cinema again, 'RRR' steps in with its brutal action sequences, extremely engaging musical numbers, a solid story, good comedy, guys holding motorcycles as weapons, and the most likable protagonists ever to give you the most entertaining three hours of the year. Hey, Hollywood, don't you dare remake this. You've been warned.

I have to admit up front, that my knowledge of Indian Cinema is zero beyond the Bollywood style movies that are the only representation that most people identify. When I heard of RRR, I thought will a three hour movie be the properI have to admit up front, that my knowledge of Indian Cinema is zero beyond the Bollywood style movies that are the only representation that most people identify. When I heard of RRR, I thought will a three hour movie be the proper introduction. In retrospect, it's like saying, gee what's this anime I'm hearing about....oh Akira?, I'll give it a watch. RRR is like Infernal Affairs on overdrive, starting with a kidnapping and developes into one of the best bromances in cinema history. There are few movies that I'll smile throughout in appreciation of the craft, ingenuity, and foremost the story...but RRR is one of those few.

An epic in every sense, even in terms of runtime, which may have benefited from fewer slow-motion moments. Each scene has magnificent visuals, and the soundtrack is a wonderful fusion of traditional and contemporary sounds. The plot isAn epic in every sense, even in terms of runtime, which may have benefited from fewer slow-motion moments. Each scene has magnificent visuals, and the soundtrack is a wonderful fusion of traditional and contemporary sounds. The plot is straightforward, but there is a lot of drama and outrageous action that intensifies as the movie goes on. The CGI is a little overdone, and the terrible British dictatorship is a touch much, but it still looks good. Although I did thought the musical performance at the end was a satire, the movie is heartwarming and hilarious at times.

With the British government ruling over India, governor Scott Buxton and wife Catherine visit a forest in Adilabad and kidnap a young girl. Bheem, the tribe's protector, heads off to Delhi to bring her back. An action-musical epic that,With the British government ruling over India, governor Scott Buxton and wife Catherine visit a forest in Adilabad and kidnap a young girl. Bheem, the tribe's protector, heads off to Delhi to bring her back. An action-musical epic that, despite it’s three hour run time, never outstays it’s welcome as it races from one fantastic scene to another.

It was entertaining. One of the most energetic, fist-pumping action films I have ever seen, so that alone pushes it into the 'good' quality. The story and protagonist characters are also good...but what lets it down are the antagonists. IIt was entertaining. One of the most energetic, fist-pumping action films I have ever seen, so that alone pushes it into the 'good' quality. The story and protagonist characters are also good...but what lets it down are the antagonists. I challenge anyone to find a more ridiculous, one-dimensional group of characters than the antagonists in this movie. Even cartoons have more nuance. But if you can get past that, absolutely worth watching.

Hey, Streamers! Word of mouth is a powerful tool in marketing a movie. I have been hearing about this epic, 3-hour action flick from India for the past few months. I heard that it was a spectacle full of high octane action sequences, musicalHey, Streamers! Word of mouth is a powerful tool in marketing a movie. I have been hearing about this epic, 3-hour action flick from India for the past few months. I heard that it was a spectacle full of high octane action sequences, musical performances and more that had to be seen to be believed. While I couldn't catch this one in the theater, Netflix has added RRR to its service. Here's how it goes.Yes, RRR is an epic, action movie about two men on a collision course with the British Empire in India. There is Bheem, who sets out to rescue Malli, a young girl from his tribe who was kidnapped by the British governor and his wicked wife. Then, there is Rama, an Indian police officer working for the British army. Bheem is fierce and ruthless, cunning and singularly focused on his goal to save Malli. Rama is equally fierce and ruthless and set on protecting the British government. As Bheem and Rama meet and become unlikely friends, secrets and hidden agendas lead to more than they both bargained for in their relationship and lead to the simmering revolutions against the British Empire.Despite its 3-hour run time, RRR is relentless. There are some lulls when the movie is setting up its plot, but it doesn't dwell much in exposition. Believe me, you may need a moment to breathe in between these action sequences. The film moves from action sequence to musical number and back. There are crazy visual effects and boundless energy coming from the screen through the camera movements and the actors.Actually, words cannot explain what this movie is really like. You just have to see it to believe it.RRR is a must-see movie. Sure, it's long, but don't let the runtime deter you. There is enough energy and action to fill the screen from beginning to end. It is surprising and worth the time spent. Grab a big box of popcorn and settle in for butt kicking and dancing and action in RRR.

I love this.I have seen some Indian movies before, and they are so bad that you just laugh.In this case, i was laughing because of the extreme emotion that this movie gives you with the ACTION
And talking about the action... it's great, ofI love this.I have seen some Indian movies before, and they are so bad that you just laugh.In this case, i was laughing because of the extreme emotion that this movie gives you with the ACTIONAnd talking about the action... it's great, of course its a bit ridiculous sometimes, and it's not realistic most of the part, but it's absolutely ADRENALINIC and EXCITINGThe ACTORS are pretty good, they do a very good jobThe STORY is simple, a Bromance with a great reveal, and it works VERY GOODThe MUSIC is subjetive, I loved it in every aspect, but I heard some people say that because of it's in its original language you can enjoy them that much, but trust me, if RRR has something good is its music, and the subtitles tell you what are they saying so that fixes the problemAll in all, it's a great movie, BUT it's 3 hours long, so you have to go to the bathroom, sit down, and prepare because you're going to see the best 3 hours 5 minutes and 24 seconds of your life.

Psycho crazy Indian 3 hour epic. Part Bromance, part musical, part Matrix. Starts off mental and by the end is totally unhinged.Just submit to it's outright stupidity and go along for the ride, it is a breakneck rollercoaster.

Rajamouli is a master of his craft. Cements himself as one of the most imaginative directors in India. Subtlety isn't his forte, and he doesn't try to go for that. What you get instead is an insane balls to the wall action movie where theRajamouli is a master of his craft. Cements himself as one of the most imaginative directors in India. Subtlety isn't his forte, and he doesn't try to go for that. What you get instead is an insane balls to the wall action movie where the action hits even harder than it looks because of the way Rajamouli organically weaves in real emotions to hyper stylized action.

While extremely over the top, RRR does this with a sense of humour, style and honestly that is sorely missing from many modern blockbuster films. I found myself absolutely enthralled for 3 hours and by the ending I was genuinely taken abackWhile extremely over the top, RRR does this with a sense of humour, style and honestly that is sorely missing from many modern blockbuster films. I found myself absolutely enthralled for 3 hours and by the ending I was genuinely taken aback at how such an indulgent and at times ridiculous film could keep me so entertained from start to finish. Hard to please everyone and there will be those who criticise realism, tear holes in the plot or claim its cliche or predictable but honestly, I think they just need to learn to have a little fun. I felt the film did an incredible job of leaning into what might be considered shortcomings in the wrong setting, and that this helped paint it more as a caricature with many nods to its own absurdity along the way. Very entertaining.

This is one of the best action flick ever made. This movie is so good that we can understand what's going on by just looking at the visuals. This movie has everything that I was missing from marvel movies since the Endgame.

The Bollywood style of filmmaking has, arguably, become a distinct genre all its own, characterized by long, visually dazzling movies filled with action sequences on steroids, hyper-energized music video segments (regardless if relevant toThe Bollywood style of filmmaking has, arguably, become a distinct genre all its own, characterized by long, visually dazzling movies filled with action sequences on steroids, hyper-energized music video segments (regardless if relevant to the story), and glamorously designed costumes, hair and makeup. It’s definitely an acquired taste and eminently commercial, but it’s not exactly something one could characterize as epic, groundbreaking cinema. Which is why I’m stunned by all of the attention and awards season buzz that’s being showered on this over-the-top offering, one that’s fairly typical of releases in this genre. In this hypothetical “what if” tale about a fictitious meeting between a pair of Indian freedom fighters who struggled against brutal British colonial rule (and who never met in real life), writer-director S.S. Rajamouli takes viewers on a whirlwind action-adventure saga that’s preposterous, predictable, clichéd, at times juvenile, and, above all, exhausting by the time one reaches the end of its 3+-hour runtime. The trite dialogue, corny narrative, cheesy CGI effects (particularly the film’s wild animals) and monodimensional characters (most notably the big bad Brits who come across more like caricatures than villains) are all laughable, almost as much as the film’s fight sequences, which play like scenes from the “John Wick” and “Matrix” franchises with a dash of martial arts flicks thrown in for good measure. In fact, were it not for the seemingly incessant runtime, this might qualify as one of those good “bad” offerings for a group movie night, though the film becomes tiresome about an hour in and can’t adequately sustain that sense of high camp for more than 180 minutes. In its defense, the picture’s choreography in the musical sequences is commendable (if at times it’s like watching a protracted aerobics class), and the costumes, art direction and set design are all noteworthy (save, of course, for a shattered marble railing in one scene that looks like the Styrofoam from which it appears to have been made). Given all of the foregoing, however, I’m truly perplexed why this release has been singled out from the other films in this genre as the beneficiary of such generous awards season recognition, perhaps other than the fact that it has been a huge box office hit worldwide, which may well have something to do with that. But is that milestone enough to drive the ample bestowing of such accolades? Remember, popcorn may qualify as a great snack, but it certainly does not a meal make.

Chaotic but in a good way is the best way to describe this movie. It’s mostly nonstop energy for the entire 3 hour runtime and that’s the best thing about this movie. The energy of this film is what makes this a must see from 2022 in my eyes.Chaotic but in a good way is the best way to describe this movie. It’s mostly nonstop energy for the entire 3 hour runtime and that’s the best thing about this movie. The energy of this film is what makes this a must see from 2022 in my eyes. The performances and characters from N.T. Rama Rao Jr. and Ram Charan are great. They both have some great chemistry together and do a great job at developing their characters. S. S. Rajamouli’s direction is really fun and so much better than his directing on Bāhubali. The action is some of the most insane I’ve seen put to film ever. It’s something that’s hard to describe and is better being seen by your own eyes. You won’t be disappointed though. It also has probably my favorite dance scene ever put to film as well. I honestly can’t think of anything that tops it. When the film isn’t action oriented or doing something fun then it can really drag. There’s a 30-40 minute portion of the film that really drags on and on. Some of the performances here aren’t exactly amazing also like from Alison Doody. If you want a really fun action and character oriented movie to watch with friends or on your own then I would highly recommend checking this out.
Must watch cause it's one of the most entertaining action movies ever made.
Awesome editing, great storytelling, powepacked bgm, very nice characterization and extremely grateful CGI to mesmerizing experience.

The positive reviews say it all. The surprises of the first climax at the two-hour mark are NOT TO BE MISSED.  Only nay sayers are likely to be gun-control enthusiasts.  "We critics occasionally forget one of the main purposes of cinema is toThe positive reviews say it all. The surprises of the first climax at the two-hour mark are NOT TO BE MISSED.  Only nay sayers are likely to be gun-control enthusiasts.  "We critics occasionally forget one of the main purposes of cinema is to entertain, impress, and have the audience simply have fun watching. “RRR” reminds us of this."Panos Kotzathanasis, Asian Movie Pulse"There are many twists as this beast punches its way through three long hours, but it moves so beautifully and is so frequently astonishing that it's well worth a look."Jeffrey M.
